conclusion: Optical Element Problem: Finding the Arc Length
Analyzing the path of light from the point source O through the optical element.
ABCO is a square with O as the center of arc AC.
The arc AC has radius R.
The material has refractive index n = 2.
Light originates from point source O.
Use Snell's law for refraction: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2).
n1 is the refractive index of the first medium (optical element, n = 2).
n2 is the refractive index of the external medium (air, n = 1).
theta1 is the angle of incidence.
theta2 is the angle of refraction.
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.
Calculate critical angle: sin(theta_c) = 1/2, theta_c = arcsin(0.5) = 30°.
Establish a coordinate system with O at the origin.
ABCO is a square with side length R, point A is at (0,R), point B is at (R,R), and point C is at (R,0).
Consider a point P on the arc AC, light ray from O to P makes an angle with the normal to the arc at that point.
Light ray is along the normal, making the angle of incidence 0°.
When light ray reaches boundaries AB or BC, it may or may not exit based on angle of incidence.
Parameterize point P on arc AC with angle phi from positive x-axis, coordinates of P are (Rcos(phi), Rsin(phi)).
For rays hitting AB, angle of incidence theta1 equals phi, total internal reflection when phi > 30°.
For rays hitting BC, angle of incidence theta1 equals (90° - phi), total internal reflection when phi < 60°.
Total internal reflection occurs when 30° < phi < 60°.
